We foster a common European culture of remembrance and dialogue on difficult issues of 20th-century European history | The European Network Remembrance and Solidarity is an international initiative whose aim is to foster international discourse on history and remembrance, with particular emphasis on periods of dictatorships, wars and resistance to political violence. The members of the Network are Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania and Slovakia, with representatives from Albania, Austria, the Czech Republic,â€¯Estonia,â€¯Georgia,â€¯Latvia andâ€¯Lithuaniaâ€¯present on its advisory bodies. Envisaged as an ever-developing project, the Networkâ€™s activities go beyond the member countries, expanding the area of dialogue about 20th-century history further afield across Europe.

August 23' Campaign ğŸ’¬ The campaign pays tribute to the victims of totalitarian regimes, marking the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Totalitarian Regimes, proclaimed by the European Parliament on the anniversary of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. This agreement between Nazism and Communism led to the tragedy of nearly 80 million people. For the tenth time, the European Network Remembrance and Solidarity (ENRS) underscores the importance of these historical events. ğŸ“– Signed in August 1939, the German-Soviet Pact paved the way for World War II and its dire consequences: mass deportations, exterminations, slave labor, war crimes, the Holocaust, and ethnic cleansing. For many European societies, it meant years of enslavement and profound losses. ğŸ“¢ The â€˜Remember. August 23' campaign aims to make August 23rd a symbol of remembrance and deepen the understanding of the struggles faced by those who lived under totalitarian regimes. ğŸ“ This Year's Campaign Highlights â¡ Short film spots: dedicated to individuals whose lives were marked by dramatic struggles against totalitarian systems. â¡ Commemorative pins: a symbolic gesture of remembrance. â¡ Media and outdoor campaigns: in selected European capitals, including posters with profiles of selected protagonists. â¡ Articles: discussing contemporary controversies surrounding the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. â¡ Guide to the Commemoration of 23 August: available on www.enrs.eu. â¡ Mural unveiling: A unique visualisation of intergenerational memory at 5 Lipowa Street, near the University of Warsaw. âœ¨ This yearâ€™s campaign heroes include: â¡ Johann Trollmann (1907â€“1944): a German boxer of Roma origin, a victim of Nazi persecution, murdered by kapo whom he had previously defeated in the ring. â¡ EmÃ­lie MachÃ¡lkovÃ¡ (1926â€“2017): a Czech woman of Roma origin, Holocaust survivor and promoter of Roma culture. In early July, deportations from the ghetto to concentration camps in Nazi Germany began. Some inhabitants tried to survive the Nazi retreat by hiding in pre-arranged hideouts, known as malinas. However, before their departure, the Gestapo set fire to the ghetto houses, shooting those attempting to escape. The fires burned throughout July. Sara GinaitÄ—-RubinsonienÄ—, a member of the Kaunas Jewish Ghetto underground, recalls: ğŸ’­ â€˜The ghetto was shrouded in smoke, through which the chimneys of the burnt-out houses were visible as if through a mist. For almost three weeks, the houses of Kaunas Ghetto were burning, the people who were hiding in them were burning, and the ground was burning... The corpses of charred people, household utensils, bedding, and photographs scattered by the wind could be seen around every house.
